bestBHT.bht: Paul rejoices upon receiving the news from Titus, who shares the Corinthians' longing desire and their zeal against sin. This brings Paul immense joy, overshadowing any grief or distress he may be facing. The Corinthians' deep repentance, evident through their tears and earnest desire to rectify past wrongs, shows their respect and remorse. The exchange of joy and comfort among believers is remarkable, as the happiness of one can bring joy and comfort to others, fostering a sense of unity and encouragement in the faith.

Henry Alford: we shared in the comfort which Titus felt in recording to us your desire
He rejoiced in announcing the news: we in hearing them
your longing desire—either longing to see me, or longing to fulfil my wishes
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He rejoiced in telling the news; we in hearing them.
They in Paul's behalf showed the zeal against the sin which Paul would have shown had he been present.
Rejoiced the more—more than before, at the mere coming of Titus.
Albert Barnes: The joy of one friend will diffuse itself through the heart of another. Joy is diffusive, and one Christian cannot well be happy without making others happy also.
Your deep repentance over the sins which had prevailed in the church.
I not only rejoiced at his coming, but I rejoiced the more at what he told me of you.
Marvin Vincent: The manner in which Paul, so to speak, fondles this word, is most beautiful."
Sorrow, as a woman, with her head bowed upon her breast; Odunh Odune, consuming Grief, follows, tearing her hair.
By her side is Odurmov Odurmos, Lamentation, a revolting, emaciated figure, whose sister is Aqumia Athumia, Despondency.
John Calvin: The occasion of his joy was, that Titus had, on returning from them, communicated the most joyful intelligence.
Their tears were a token of respect; because, being affected with his reproof, they mourned over their sins.
So that all my griefs and distresses gave way to joy.
Archibald T. Robertson: The manner in which Paul, so to speak, fondles this word (παρακαλεω) is most beautiful."
Result expressed by ωστε and the second aorist passive infinitive of χαιρω with accusative of general reference.
John Gill: The joys and comforts of one believer yield a considerable pleasure, and are matter of joy and comfort, to another.
The grief and sorrow occasioned hereby to the apostle.
His joy on this narrative of things abundantly exceeded his troubles and afflictions, which surrounded him on every side, and overcame and extinguished that sorrow.
John Wesley: Your earnest desire — To rectify what had been amiss.
Your grief — For what had offended God, and troubled me.

bhtAttempts.bht: In 2 Corinthians 7:7, the apostle Paul expresses his joy upon hearing the news from Titus about the Corinthians' longing desire and their zeal against sin. The joy of one friend easily spreads to another, and Paul's happiness is evident as he fondly boasts about their desire to please him and God. Despite the grief and sorrows he faced, this news brought him immeasurable joy. The deep repentance and tears shed by the Corinthians showed their respect and sincere regret for their sins. Their earnest desire to rectify what had been amiss gave Paul reason to rejoice even more. Truly, the joys and comforts of one believer can greatly impact and bring joy and comfort to others.

In this passage, Paul shares his joy upon hearing the news from Titus about the Corinthians' longing desire and their zeal against sin. The joy of one friend easily spreads to another, and Paul's happiness is evident as he fondly boasts about their desire to please him and God. Despite the grief and sorrows he faced, this news brought him immeasurable joy. The deep repentance and tears shed by the Corinthians showed their respect and sincere regret for their sins. Their earnest desire to rectify what had been amiss gave Paul reason to rejoice even more. Truly, the joys and comforts of one believer can greatly impact and bring joy and comfort to others.

In this verse, Paul joyfully receives news from Titus about the Corinthians' longing desire and their steadfastness against sin. This joyful announcement brings Paul immeasurable happiness, outweighing any grief or hardship he experiences. The Corinthians' deep repentance, marked by tears and a sincere desire to rectify past mistakes, demonstrates their respect and genuine remorse. This exchange of joy and comfort among believers is evident, where one's happiness becomes a source of joy and encouragement for others.

Paul rejoices upon receiving the news from Titus, who shares the Corinthians' longing desire and their zeal against sin. This brings Paul immense joy, overshadowing any grief or distress he may be facing. The Corinthians' deep repentance, evident through their tears and earnest desire to rectify past wrongs, shows their respect and remorse. The exchange of joy and comfort among believers is remarkable, as the happiness of one can bring joy and comfort to others, fostering a sense of unity and encouragement in the faith.

Paul finds great joy upon receiving news from Titus about the Corinthians' longing desire and their zeal against sin. Despite any grief or distress he may experience, this news brings him immense happiness. The Corinthians' deep repentance, expressed through tears and their sincere desire to rectify past mistakes, reveals their respect and regret. The exchange of joy and comfort among believers is remarkable, as one believer's joy can bring joy and comfort to others. Such unity and encouragement within the faith is truly significant.
